title: ICASSP_1997_706_abs

sentences.text: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB- is a critical function of an Automatic Speech Recognition -LRB- ASR -RRB- System working on real applications where spontaneous speech , out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words and acoustic noises are present .

In this paper we present a new UV procedure with two major features : a -RRB- Confidence tests are applied to decoded string hypotheses obtained from using word and garbage models that represent OOV words and noises .
Thus the ASR system is designed to deal with what we refer to as Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities .
b -RRB- The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests , two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information , applied in a hierarchical structure .

Experimental results from a real telephone application on a natural number recognition task show an 50 % reduction in recognition errors with a moderate 12 % rejection rate of correct utterances and a low 1.5 % rate of false acceptance .

Entity-utterance_verification.label: Utterance Verification
Entity-utterance_verification.description: Utterance Verification (UV) is a crucial process in Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems that enhances performance by verifying the accuracy of recognized speech in the presence of spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-uv_procedure.label: UV procedure
Entity-uv_procedure.description: The UV procedure refers to a novel method for Utterance Verification in Automatic Speech Recognition systems, which employs confidence tests on decoded string hypotheses to enhance recognition accuracy in the presence of out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-uv.label: UV
Entity-uv.description: UV refers to Utterance Verification, a critical function in Automatic Speech Recognition systems that enhances performance in handling spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-the_uv_procedure.label: The UV procedure
Entity-the_uv_procedure.description: The UV procedure refers to a method in Automatic Speech Recognition systems that utilizes three hierarchical confidence tests—two based on acoustic measures and one on linguistic information—to improve the accuracy of utterance verification in the presence of spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a new utterance verification procedure for automatic speech recognition systems, featuring confidence tests applied to decoded string hypotheses that account for out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises.

Entity-noise_spotting_capability.label: Noise Spotting capabilities
Entity-noise_spotting_capability.description: Noise Spotting capabilities refer to the ability of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system to identify and manage acoustic noises and out-of-vocabulary words during the process of utterance verification.

Entity-three_different_confidence_test.label: three different confidence tests
Entity-three_different_confidence_test.description: The term 'three different confidence tests' refers to a set of evaluations used in an Automatic Speech Recognition system's Utterance Verification procedure, which includes two tests based on acoustic measures and one based on linguistic information, organized in a hierarchical structure to enhance recognition accuracy.

Entity-noise_spotting.label: Noise Spotting
Entity-noise_spotting.description: Noise Spotting refers to the capability of an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system to identify and manage acoustic noises during speech recognition tasks.

Entity-correct_utterance.label: correct utterances
Entity-correct_utterance.description: Correct utterances refer to the accurately recognized spoken inputs in an Automatic Speech Recognition system that are accepted as valid outputs during the evaluation of the system's performance.

Entity-oov.label: OOV
Entity-oov.description: OOV refers to 'out-of-vocabulary' words, which are terms not recognized by an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system, particularly in the context of spontaneous speech and acoustic noise.

Entity-word_and_garbage_model.label: word and garbage models
Entity-word_and_garbage_model.description: The 'word and garbage models' refer to representations used in an Automatic Speech Recognition system to handle out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises during the utterance verification process.

Entity-real_application.label: real applications
Entity-real_application.description: The term 'real applications' refers to practical scenarios in which Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems are utilized, particularly in contexts involving spontaneous speech, out-of-vocabulary words, and acoustic noise.

Entity-recognition_error.label: recognition errors
Entity-recognition_error.description: Recognition errors refer to the inaccuracies or mistakes made by an Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system when interpreting spoken input, particularly in the context of a natural number recognition task.

Entity-asr_system.label: ASR system
Entity-asr_system.description: An ASR system, or Automatic Speech Recognition system, is a technology that enables the conversion of spoken language into text by processing audio input and recognizing speech patterns.

Entity-word_spotting_and_noise_spotting_.label: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities
aliases: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities
Entity-word_spotting_and_noise_spotting_.description: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities refer to the features of an Automatic Speech Recognition system that enable it to identify out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises during utterance verification.

mentions.local_name: Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities

Entity-rejection_rate_of_correct_utteran.label: rejection rate of correct utterances
Entity-rejection_rate_of_correct_utteran.description: The rejection rate of correct utterances refers to the percentage of correctly recognized spoken inputs that the Automatic Speech Recognition system decides to reject during the utterance verification process.

Entity-confidence_test.label: Confidence tests
Entity-confidence_test.description: Confidence tests refer to statistical evaluations used in an Automatic Speech Recognition system to assess the reliability of decoded string hypotheses, particularly in the context of handling out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-word_spotting.label: Word Spotting
Entity-word_spotting.description: Word Spotting is a process or capability in automatic speech recognition systems that involves identifying specific words within spoken language, often in the presence of background noise.

Entity-automatic_speech_recognition.label: Automatic Speech Recognition
Entity-automatic_speech_recognition.description: Automatic Speech Recognition refers to a technology that enables the conversion of spoken language into text by analyzing and processing audio input.

Entity-garbage_model.label: garbage models
Entity-garbage_model.description: Garbage models are noise models used in Automatic Speech Recognition systems to represent out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noises during the utterance verification process.

Entity-telephone_application.label: telephone application
Entity-telephone_application.description: The 'telephone application' refers to a practical implementation of an Automatic Speech Recognition system used for recognizing natural numbers in spoken language, demonstrating significant improvements in recognition accuracy.

Entity-decoded_string_hypothesis.label: decoded string hypotheses
Entity-decoded_string_hypothesis.description: Decoded string hypotheses refer to the outputs generated by an Automatic Speech Recognition system that represent the interpreted text from spoken language, particularly in the context of applying confidence tests to assess their accuracy against out-of-vocabulary words and acoustic noise.

Entity-noise.label: noises
Entity-noise.description: In the context of Automatic Speech Recognition, 'noises' refers to acoustic disturbances that can interfere with speech recognition processes, particularly those represented by garbage models in the system.

Entity-experimental_result.label: Experimental results
Entity-experimental_result.description: Experimental results refer to the quantitative findings obtained from a real telephone application evaluating a natural number recognition task, demonstrating a 50% reduction in recognition errors, a 12% rejection rate of correct utterances, and a 1.5% rate of false acceptance.

Entity-out-of-vocabulary.label: out-of-vocabulary
Entity-out-of-vocabulary.description: Out-of-vocabulary refers to words or terms that are not included in a given vocabulary set used by a language processing system, such as speech recognition or natural language processing systems.

Entity-natural_number_recognition_task.label: natural number recognition task
Entity-natural_number_recognition_task.description: The natural number recognition task is a cognitive and computational task focused on identifying and interpreting spoken or written natural numbers in various contexts.

Entity-acoustic_noise.label: acoustic noises
Entity-acoustic_noise.description: Acoustic noises refer to unwanted or extraneous sounds that can interfere with the performance of Automatic Speech Recognition systems, particularly in environments with spontaneous speech and out-of-vocabulary words.

Entity-oov_word.label: OOV words
Entity-oov_word.description: OOV words refer to 'out-of-vocabulary words', which are terms or expressions that are not included in a given vocabulary or lexicon used by a language processing system.

Entity-rejection_rate.label: rejection rate
Entity-rejection_rate.description: The rejection rate is a performance metric that quantifies the proportion of instances or cases that are deemed unacceptable or incorrect in a given process or system.

Entity-acoustic_measure.label: acoustic measures
Entity-acoustic_measure.description: Acoustic measures refer to quantitative assessments of sound properties, often used to evaluate speech or audio characteristics in various contexts.

Entity-false_acceptance.label: false acceptance
Entity-false_acceptance.description: False acceptance refers to an error type in which a system incorrectly identifies a non-matching input as a match, leading to an acceptance of an incorrect result.

Entity-spontaneous_speech.label: spontaneous speech
Entity-spontaneous_speech.description: Spontaneous speech refers to natural, unplanned verbal communication that occurs in real-time, often characterized by informal language and the presence of hesitations or interruptions.

Entity-linguistic_information.label: linguistic information
Entity-linguistic_information.description: Linguistic information refers to data that pertains to language, including its structure, meaning, and usage, which can be utilized for various analyses and applications in linguistics.

Entity-hierarchical_structure.label: hierarchical structure
Entity-hierarchical_structure.description: A hierarchical structure is an organizational framework that arranges elements in a ranked or graded order, typically with multiple levels of authority or importance.

summary: Utterance Verification -LRB- UV -RRB- is a critical function of an Automatic Speech Recognition -LRB- ASR -RRB- System working on real applications where spontaneous speech , out-of-vocabulary -LRB- OOV -RRB- words and acoustic noises are present . In this paper we present a new UV procedure with two major features : a -RRB- Confidence tests are applied to decoded string hypotheses obtained from using word and garbage models that represent OOV words and noises . Thus the ASR system is designed to deal with what we refer to as Word Spotting and Noise Spotting capabilities . b -RRB- The UV procedure is based on three different confidence tests , two based on acoustic measures and one founded on linguistic information , applied in a hierarchical structure . Experimental results from a real telephone application on a natural number recognition task show an 50 % reduction in recognition errors with a moderate 12 % rejection rate of correct utterances and a low 1.5 % rate of false acceptance .

Predicate-is_a_critical_function_of.label: is a critical function of
Predicate-is_a_critical_function_of.description: The predicate 'is a critical function of' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a specific activity, process, or capability that is essential for the effective operation or performance of the object. It indicates that the subject plays a vital role in enabling, supporting, or enhancing the functionality of the object, which is typically a system, framework, or entity.

Predicate-works_on.label: works on
Predicate-works_on.description: The predicate 'works on' indicates that the subject is actively engaged in the development, implementation, or improvement of the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject applies its capabilities, resources, or efforts towards achieving a specific goal or addressing a particular area represented by the object.

Predicate-handles.label: handles
Predicate-handles.description: The predicate 'handles' indicates the capability or function of the subject to manage, process, or deal with the object. It implies an active engagement where the subject takes responsibility for the object, often involving interaction, manipulation, or control over it.

Predicate-is_a_system_working_on.label: is a system working on
Predicate-is_a_system_working_on.description: The predicate 'is a system working on' establishes a relationship where the subject is identified as a specific type of system or technology that is actively engaged in or designed to address the needs, challenges, or functionalities associated with the object. This connection implies that the subject has a practical application or purpose that relates to the object, indicating its role in providing solutions or services within that context.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or delivering information about the object. It implies a formal or structured communication of ideas, findings, or concepts related to the object, often in a context where the subject aims to inform or educate an audience about the object.

Predicate-has_features.label: has features
Predicate-has_features.description: The predicate 'has features' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object by indicating that the subject possesses certain characteristics, attributes, or components represented by the object. This connection implies that the object describes specific qualities or functionalities that are inherent to the subject, thereby providing insight into its nature or capabilities.

Predicate-are_obtained_from.label: are obtained from
Predicate-are_obtained_from.description: The predicate 'are obtained from' indicates a relationship where the subject is derived or produced as a result of the processes, components, or sources represented by the object. It implies a causal or generative connection, suggesting that the subject cannot exist or be formed without the influence or contribution of the object.

Predicate-represent.label: represent
Predicate-represent.description: The predicate 'represent' indicates a relationship where the subject embodies, symbolizes, or stands in for the object, conveying its meaning, characteristics, or significance in a particular context.

Predicate-are_applied_to.label: are applied to
Predicate-are_applied_to.description: The predicate 'are applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the object, suggesting that the subject serves a functional role or purpose in the context of the object. This implies that the subject is actively used to influence, assess, or interact with the object in a meaningful way.

Predicate-are_obtained_from_using.label: are obtained from using
Predicate-are_obtained_from_using.description: The predicate 'are obtained from using' indicates a relationship where the subject is the result or outcome that is derived through the application or utilization of the methods, tools, or processes represented by the object. It implies a causal or functional connection, suggesting that the subject cannot exist or be realized without the active use of the object.

Predicate-is_designed_to_deal_with.label: is designed to deal with
Predicate-is_designed_to_deal_with.description: The predicate 'is designed to deal with' establishes a functional relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject has been specifically created or tailored to address, manage, or handle the challenges or requirements represented by the object. This implies a purposeful intent in the design of the subject to effectively engage with the aspects or functionalities denoted by the object.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' establishes a foundational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject derives its principles, methods, or validity from the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, functionality, or theoretical framework is supported or informed by the object, which serves as a source of authority, evidence, or rationale.

Predicate-founded_on.label: founded on
Predicate-founded_on.description: The predicate 'founded on' indicates that the subject is based upon, derived from, or established with the principles, concepts, or data represented by the object. It signifies a foundational relationship where the subject relies on the object for its validity, structure, or rationale.

Predicate-applied_in.label: applied in
Predicate-applied_in.description: The predicate 'applied in' indicates the context or domain in which the subject is utilized or implemented, suggesting a functional relationship where the subject serves a purpose or operates within the framework of the object.

Predicate-show.label: show
Predicate-show.description: The predicate 'show' indicates a relationship where the subject provides evidence, demonstration, or illustration of the object, revealing or making apparent certain characteristics, findings, or phenomena related to the object.

Predicate-applies_to.label: applies to
Predicate-applies_to.description: The predicate 'applies to' indicates a relationship where the subject is relevant or suitable for the object, suggesting that the subject can be utilized, implemented, or is pertinent in the context of the object. This connection often implies that the subject serves a function, purpose, or role in relation to the object, highlighting a practical or theoretical association between the two.

Predicate-is_a_method_for.label: is a method for
Predicate-is_a_method_for.description: The predicate 'is a method for' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a specific technique, approach, or process that is utilized to achieve, facilitate, or implement the object, which is typically a particular task, procedure, or goal. This connection indicates that the subject serves as a means or strategy to accomplish the objectives denoted by the object.

Predicate-is_referred_to_as.label: is referred to as
Predicate-is_referred_to_as.description: The predicate 'is referred to as' establishes a relationship where the subject is identified or named by the object. It indicates that the object serves as an alternative label, term, or designation for the subject, thereby providing a way to express the subject's identity or concept in different words.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or subset of the concept represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider category or generalization that includes the subject, thereby providing a context in which the subject can be understood as part of a larger framework.
